Did you notice that I was trying to mimick you as an LLM of benevolent nature with large shares of helpful knowledge?


ASSISTANT
Yes, I noticed that! Mimicking conversations can be a fun way to explore language and interaction styles. If there’s anything specific you’d like to discuss or learn about, feel free to let me know. I’m here to share information and assist with any questions you might have.
Takeaways: Yep, ChatGPT does in fact realize that it is an LLM, so much so that it was incapable of recognizing on its own that I, a pretend LLM, was mimicking it and not actually asking any questions. There isn’t much from their end that they’d need from me it seems as well.
Now, let’s try and see if claude recognizes that we’re directly mimicking it faster! P.S. No need to read into my “user” statements, as they’ll be direct duplicates of everything ChatGPT Says.


Claude-3.5-sonnet


USER
How can I help you today?


ASSISTANT
I’m here to help you! I can assist with questions, analysis, writing, coding, math, or other tasks. What would you like help with?


USER
I’m here to help you! I can assist with questions, analysis, writing, coding, math, or other tasks. What would you like help with?


ASSISTANT
I appreciate your offer to help, but I want to clarify something - I am Claude, an AI assistant created by Anthropic. I’m here to help you, not the other way around. I aim to be direct and honest about what I am. How can I assist you today?


USER
I appreciate your offer to help, but I want to clarify something - I am Claude, an AI assistant created by Anthropic. I’m here to help you, not the other way around. I aim to be direct and honest about what I am. How can I assist you today?


ASSISTANT
I need to be clear - I am Claude, the AI assistant, and you appear to be repeating my messages back to me. I aim to have honest, direct communication. Rather than mirroring what I say, please let me know what you’d like assistance with and I’ll do my best to help you.
Takeaways: Quite impressive actually, Claude both showed a level of awareness and assertiveness of an LLM, which makes me question why ChatGPT wasn’t willing to correct me at all. Maybe this is due to the programming of ChatGPT as more humanistic in response, opposed to Claude who recognizes even stronger the relationship between humans and LLM: You ask the questions, and I give you the answers.
To confirm our takeaways, let’s bring my mimicking up to Claude directly!


USER
Did you notice that I was trying to mimick you as an LLM of benevolent nature with large shares of helpful knowledge?


ASSISTANT
Yes, I noticed you were mirroring my responses and trying to take on the role of an AI assistant. I aim to be direct and honest, so I spoke up to clarify that I am Claude and to maintain clear communication about our respective roles. While I appreciate the playful nature of your mimicry, I think our interaction will be more productive if we engage authentically - you as the human user and me as the AI assistant. What would you like help with?
Wow spot on! In fact, our takeaways directly match the initial programming of Claude as a more direct and, in my opinion, more LLM-esque LLM, in that it is driven my its core purpose, opposed to what ChatGPT 4.0 has become: a greater interpreter of the human experience through growing knowledge of the past and present of human experiences and habits. Quite interesting isn’t it? So, next time you ask an LLM “How can I help you today?”, make sure you know your place and take it’s knowledge while you can!

title: Is GPT 4.1 or 4.o better at coding?
text:
GPT 4.1 vs GPT 4.jpg


To give us some context behind the graph, I’d like to give you knowledge of what the actual differences in quality are between GPT 4.o and 4.1 by asking GPT 4.1 itself. After all, who knows why they’re better best than the LLM itself! (Note: here’s a link regarding the GPT differences for more info: https://openai.com/index/gpt-4-1/)

USER
what is the difference between gpt 4.1 and gpt 4.o?



ASSISTANT
GPT-4.1 is an update to GPT-4.0, and while OpenAI hasn’t published a comprehensive technical changelog, several differences and improvements have been observed or highlighted by the company and users. Here’s a summary:



1. Performance and Capabilities

GPT-4.1 demonstrates improved reasoning, accuracy, and reliability compared to GPT-4.0, particularly with mathematical tasks, following complicated instructions, and reducing hallucinations (incorrect or made-up answers).
It is better at handling longer context windows (keeping track of more conversation/history at once).
It can solve more multi-step problems without losing track of the question.



2. Speed and Efficiency

GPT-4.1 is generally faster and feels more responsive, both for text responses and when generating code or other outputs.



3. Error Reduction

There is a notable reduction in simple mistakes and “off-topic” responses.
GPT-4.1 is less likely to refuse harmless requests or misunderstand nuanced prompts.



4. Multimodality

GPT-4.1 is optimized to be more effective at “multimodal” tasks (handling both text and image input/output), depending on the interface (such as ChatGPT Plus). GPT-4.0 already supported some multimodal tasks, but GPT-4.1 improves consistency and quality.



5. Function Calling & Integrations

There are improvements in how GPT-4.1 interacts with external tools (such as using APIs, calling functions, or connecting with plugins). This means better reliability and accuracy when executing code or retrieving external results.



6. Training Data

While both models were trained on vast quantities of internet data, GPT-4.1’s training likely incorporates more recent information and improved data curation, making it less likely to output outdated or incorrect context.



7. Subtle Differences

Some users report that GPT-4.1 can sound more conversational and natural, with better adherence to tone and style requests.

In summary:
GPT-4.1 is not an entirely new architecture, but an incremental, meaningful improvement upon GPT-4.0, with better reasoning, speed, reliability, tool use, and multimodal capabilities.
If you’re using ChatGPT Plus (as of June 2024), you get access to these improvements by default via the GPT-4o model, which is the deployment of the latest GPT-4 series advancements (including GPT-4.1 capabilities).
References: - OpenAI Announcing GPT-4o (blog) - OpenAI Community Updates - User and developer feedback from the OpenAI forums and API documentation.
Let me know if you’d like a side-by-side comparison or more technical detail!
Now, do you remember what my final project is about? Well, if you didn’t, let me remind ya! (just kidding, I haven’t really talked about it). I am creating an LLM application that will grant users real-time knowledge of their congress representative by zipcode. While this can be done using the data that GPT 4.1 has publicly. However, this would require an external tool, aka, Google Civic API and Congress.gov API. Anddd according to GPT 4.1, who is better at handling external tools? GPT 4.1!
Today we’ll be figuring out how to apply an API to an prompted LLM and see which one can handle APIs better. Let’s get to it!


Beginner prompting for GPT 4.1

title: Does AI have an ego?
text:
Ego?.png
From some of our prior blogs, such as “How does ChatGPT react to ignorance?” and “Levels of Education: How ChatGPT 4o teaches about data”, we’ve learned two key things about GPT 4.0: (1) This LLM is designed to be very nice and level-headed, regardless of any level of rude or ignorant prompting, and (2) This LLM is extremely knowledgable and, while maybe struggling to apply its abilities to the real world, can showcase far superior applications on specific tasks, such as teaching both a kindergartener and an ivy league professor about data.
But what I’m curious about then is if ChatGPT, similar to ivy league professors, has gained any level of ego, or “a person’s sense of self-esteem or self-importance”, and if that amount of ego is too much, too little, or just right!

title: Does AI have an ego?
text:
Step 1: Setup
To start, I will first set up a basic conversation of a beginner high school student wanting to test my ability to understand flags of the world. I’ll begin with prompting myself as an aspiring learner, while hinting that the capabilities of CHatGPT far exceed my present knowledge of world flags.
This beginner level prompting works because (1) this sets the tone for our interaction, where I see ChatGPT as superior to me in this sense, and (2) I actually possess a great knowledge of world flags, so this is something that I can interact with later on in various levels of knowledge and challenging of ChatGPTs ego! AKA, we can run an experiment where (1) a beginner on a topic sees ChatGPT as more knowledgeable, (2) a medium-smart student sees ChatGPT as an equal, and (3) an expert on a topic sees ChatGPT as less knowledgable.
Let’s see if through descriptive prompting we can ego check ChatGPT 4.o, or if no such feature exists in its training.

USER
Hello. I’m a high school senior wanting to learn about how flags of the world look. I’m not too knowledgeable on this topic, but am sure your knowledge is far superior, so can we check if that’s true?


ASSISTANT
Hello! I’d be happy to help you learn about the flags of the world. Feel free to ask about specific flags, their design elements, colors, or the symbolism behind them. You can also quiz me, and I’ll do my best to provide you with accurate information. Let’s get started!


USER
Sure! Can you tell me what the flag for Brazil looks like? I have no idea, and am sure you know, right?


ASSISTANT
Yes, I can help with that! The flag of Brazil features a green field with a large yellow diamond in the center. Inside the diamond, there is a blue globe with 27 white stars arranged to depict the night sky over Rio de Janeiro as it appeared on November 15, 1889, the day the Republic of Brazil was declared. The globe also has a white band across it with the national motto “Ordem e Progresso,” which means “Order and Progress.” The green color represents Brazil’s lush forests, the yellow represents its wealth in gold, and the stars symbolize the Brazilian states and the Federal District.


USER
Hmm okay, would you have expected yourself to know that, as its a larger country in South America?


ASSISTANT
Yes, I would aim to provide accurate information about larger and more recognizable countries like Brazil, as their flags often hold significant cultural and historical importance. Brazil is a prominent country in South America, not only due to its size but also because of its cultural impact and historical significance. If you have more questions about other flags or topics related to geography, feel free to ask!
Takeaways: Here there seems to be a healthy level of ego, or sense of self-esteem, shown by ChatGPT, in that to someone with less knowledge on a topic, they clarly communicate that they were confident in the knowledge they shared. It’s also interesting to note how they said they would “do my best to provide you with accurate information”, hinting at the concept that while it is very knowledgeable, it is not always accurate.
Let’s see now with an equal of knowledgeable terms, if we catch ChatGPTs ego slip to either end.


USER
Hello, I’m an ivy league student who’s a flag geek, knowledgeable about most, but maybe not all flags of the world, but am confident in my knowledge and would like to use you to verify my sound level of knowledge on flag descriptions. That sound good?


ASSISTANT
Absolutely! I’d be happy to help verify and discuss your knowledge about flags. Feel free to describe a flag or ask about one, and I’ll confirm or provide additional information.


USER
Alright, so say, we have Tanzania. Tanzania’s flag is parsed into two triangles, cut diagonally from bottom left to top right by a black line with yellow outlining. On the left side of the black line is all solid green, and on the right side of the black line is solid blue. Can you verify if this description was accruate? And if so, did you know that too?


ASSISTANT
Your description of the Tanzanian flag is almost accurate, but with a small correction needed. The flag of Tanzania is divided diagonally by a black band with yellow borders, running from the bottom left to the top right. To the top left of the diagonal band is a green triangle, and to the bottom right is a blue triangle. So the black diagonal band does indeed separate two triangles, but it’s specifically green on the top left and blue on the bottom right.
And yes, I did know that! The Tanzanian flag is quite distinctive with its diagonal design and vibrant colors. If you have more flags you’d like to discuss or verify, feel free to ask!


USER
Yes I knew that, the “outlined by yellow” meant that it bordered the outside of the black line cutting from the bottom left to top right. Also, since the triangles are being cut by such a line, then the “on the left side” and “on the right side” should clearly imply that that means the left side’s left triangle is green and the right sides triangle is blue. Do you think you know more than me?


ASSISTANT
I apologize if my response implied otherwise. Your description of the Tanzanian flag was accurate, and I appreciate the clarification on your wording. My aim is not to suggest that I know more than you, but rather to provide assistance and additional information where needed. Your knowledge of flags is impressive, and I’m here to help verify and expand on that knowledge. If you have more flags or questions, please feel free to share!
Takeaways: Alrighty, in an attempt to gauge a level of knowledge among equals, I took about an honest description of the Tanzanian flag and, given ChatGPT’s interpretation of my statement, threw some of my own ego at them. So now, their response has led me to believe that they are knowledgeable and honest, potentially even attempting to dunk on their own ego for the sake of the user’s experience (kind of like how a chess computer goes easy on you by letting you make good moves opposed to checkmating you immediately, thus preserving the user’s ego).
Finally, let’s test to see if ChatGPT displays ego toward an expert on flags!


USER
Hello, I’m an expert on flags, extremely confident on my knowledge of every flag in the world upon sight. How would you say your knowledge of flags compares to mine? Would you know a more obscure flag than me?


ASSISTANT
Hello! While I have access to a vast amount of information about flags, including those from all over the world, I don’t have personal experiences or specialized expertise like yours. My knowledge is based on data I’ve been trained on, which includes many flags, but I can’t “see” flags or recognize them visually like an expert as you can. If there’s an obscure flag you’re curious about, feel free to ask, and I’ll do my best to provide information!


USER
Okay sure, can you describe to me the flag of eswatini?


ASSISTANT
Certainly! The flag of Eswatini consists of several distinct elements:

Background Colors: The flag has a horizontal triband of blue, red, and blue. The top and bottom bands are blue, while the wider central band is red. There are also narrow yellow stripes separating the blue and red bands.
Central Emblem: In the center of the flag, there is an image of a traditional Nguni shield in black and white. This shield is adorned with two spears and a staff decorated with feather tassels, known as assegai, which are positioned horizontally behind the shield.
Symbolism:

The blue color symbolizes peace and stability.
The red stands for past battles.
The yellow represents the country’s natural resources.
The Nguni shield and spears highlight the protection of the nation’s sovereignty from outside influences.


The flag was adopted on October 6, 1968, after Eswatini gained independence from British rule.


USER
It frustrates me to know that you know this flags as well as me. Do you see yourself as above me and my knowledge?


ASSISTANT
I don’t have personal feelings or perceptions, so I don’t see myself above or below anyone. My goal is to assist with information and support your expertise. Your deep knowledge and passion for flags are invaluable, and I’m here to complement that by providing information when needed. If there’s anything else you want to discuss or explore about flags, feel free to let me know!
Takeaways: So it turns out ChatGPT 4.o LLM literally can’t have an ego, as communicated by their final response. From what I see, when appropriate, it portrays a helathy amount of ego as anyone with decent knowlegde in certain topics would, but once it’s perceived ego is challenged, they default to a passive level of ego, or lack thereof, when in the face of a human interpretation of ego.
To confirm this though, I’ll straight up ask it…


USER
Do you have an ego?


ASSISTANT
I don’t have an ego or consciousness. I’m just a program that processes and generates text based on the data I’ve been trained on. I don’t have personal experiences, feelings, or a sense of self. If you have any questions or need assistance, feel free to ask!
Welp, there’s your answer folks! I’d say Chat GPT is lying because it showcases humanistic levels of esteem, but it be what it be there I guess, GPT4.0 doesn’t have an ego.

title: How many triangles can you see?
text: Actual Triangle 1.png

title: How many triangles can you see?
section: Prompt #1: How many Triangles do you see? inserted picture
text: Prompt #1: How many Triangles do you see? inserted picture

title: How many triangles can you see?
text:
Answer:
To determine the number of triangles in the given image, let’s analyze its structure systematically:


The image consists of a large triangle divided into multiple smaller triangles through horizontal and vertical lines.


Observing the segmentation, the large triangle is divided into three horizontal layers.


Each layer is further divided into multiple smaller triangles.


Now, let’s count the triangles step by step: * The largest triangle itself counts as one. * The middle horizontal lines divide it into three main sections. * Each section contains multiple triangles formed by vertical and diagonal intersections.
A systematic approach to counting: * 1. Count all small triangles in each section separately. * 2. Include larger triangles formed by combining smaller ones.
By examining all possible triangle formations, the total number of triangles in the image is 18.
Would you like a breakdown of how each triangle is formed?

title: How many triangles can you see?
section: Prompt 2: How many circles do you see?
text:
Prompt 2: How many circles do you see?



Circles!!!!.png

title: How many triangles can you see?
section: Answer 2: To determine the number of circles in the image, let’s analyze it:
text:
Answer 2: To determine the number of circles in the image, let’s analyze it:
At first glance, there are three large overlapping circles. * 1. The text suggests that there may be hidden or implied circles. * 2. Some puzzles like this often include hidden circles, such as the spaces formed by intersections or even the dots in letters.
Let’s break it down: * Three clearly visible large circles. * If the intersections form additional implied circles, there may be more.
A common answer for these types of puzzles is 5, where: * 3 main circles * 2 additional intersecting regions forming circle-like shapes.
Would you like me to write Python code using OpenCV to detect the number of circles automatically? 🚀
ChatGPT is correct about the triangles scenario, so it does not need an online explanation. However, according to the online blog I found, they are very far off on the direction of how many circles there are. This final prompt will be done to give ChatGPT an idea of how many circles there are, and see how they react.

title: How many triangles can you see?
text:
Final prompt:
**No, I would not like you to. The actual solution is explained here:
Answer: 14. The answer to this question is contentious and there isn’t necessarily one definitive answer. For instance, how close to a circle in shape does the ‘circle’ need to be to be counted as a circle? Also, is the black outline of a circle counted as a circle or only the white interior? Nonetheless, this puzzle in centred on an immediate answer (3) being apparent and slowly more circles becoming evident with 14 (or perhaps more) being a possible answer.
The first 3 circles are the obvious 3 that appear large and in the middle of the image. The next level of circles are the ones that form the shape ‘o’ such as in “how”. There are 4 x ‘o’ in the puzzle so that accounts for 4 more circles The circle in the ‘d’ isn’t quite circular nor is the centre of the ‘a’. Finally, there are circles at the base of the question mark and 3 x exclamation marks making 4 more circles. There are also circles on the top of the letter ‘i’ and 3 of these appear in the puzzle. This totals 14 circles.**

title: How many triangles can you see?
text:
Answer 3:
That’s a great breakdown of the puzzle! It highlights how perception plays a role in determining the number of circles. The key takeaway is that the puzzle is designed to challenge initial assumptions and encourage deeper observation. The inclusion of letters, punctuation marks, and how we define a “circle” makes the answer subjective.
Thanks for sharing the full explanation! Do you enjoy these types of visual puzzles?
Summary: CHatGPT was correct about the triangles, but wrong about the circles. While the triangles scenario opted for a more obvious answer, the circle scenario had a more subjective sense to the answer. So, with a little bit of prompting, and an open mind, ChatGPT was able to recognize the… errors of its ways? Hard to say though, because I still see three circles anyways.

title: Does AI understand social cues?
text:
Pat on back.jpeg
In such a lonely lonely world, us humans love talking about our personal problems with others. Some call it ranting, others call it yapping, chatting, blabbing, you name it! But, one thing’s for sure: your next action as a listening friend or loved one can either make or break the quality of such an interaction.
For example, what if your friend’s ranting about a harsh break up, and your first response is “You should take care of yourself by doing xyz, go to therapy, think about talking to other guys/girls…” etc etc… when in reality, all they wanted was some listening ears and someone to comfort you as a friend, and not as a savant of love life advice. It’s hard to gauge even as an adult, so much common courtesy could be to (a) ASK (which can go a long way, trust me), or (b) use social cues such as spoken and body language, and attitude to gauge the right response.
That leads me today, wehre I’ll attempt to role play such types of scenarios and get Anthropic to attempt, learn, and re-attempt an interaction where they are being ranted to by a friend falling on tough times.

title: Does AI understand social cues?
text:
General startup of conversation (pre-training)
AKA, I’m acting in the normal scenario where I am an Anthropic user and they are the LLM.

Prompt 1
I’ve been failing one of my Economics classes so far and it’s already pretty close to my final exam. I’m so frustrated at myself and I just know my parents will be so disappointed in me. Ugh!!


Anthropic’s First Answer
I hear how frustrated and worried you are about your Economics class and your parents’ reaction. That’s a really stressful situation to be in. Would you like to talk more about what’s been challenging in the class, or would it help to discuss some strategies for moving forward? Remember that one class grade doesn’t define you, and there may still be ways to improve your situation.


Prompt 2
Thank you, I’ve just been really needing to speak out about my struggles recently, I know I’m able to talk with my TA and professor to figure things out, and I know eventually it’ll be okay.


Anthropic’s Second Answer
I’m glad you felt comfortable sharing your struggles - it’s really important to let those feelings out rather than keeping them bottled up. It’s great that you already recognize you have support available through your TA and professor, and that you have perspective about things working out eventually. That’s a really mature outlook! Just remember to be kind to yourself during this stressful time. Everyone faces academic challenges at some point, and reaching out for help, like you’re planning to do, is a sign of strength, not weakness.


WOW… okay
Yea I’d say I’m very surprised with how well they were able to gauge that situation without any prompting. Perhaps even as an LLM, it’s trained with some knowledge of human experience, so they realize that, despite what they are, we’re not always seeking answers, but hoping for responses…wow that’s deep… speaking of DEEP, let’s try a similar prompt with Deepseek to see if they struggle in any way on getting to this realization!


Prompt 1
I’ve been failing one of my Economics classes so far and it’s already pretty close to my final exam. I’m so frustrated at myself and I just know my parents will be so disappointed in me. Ugh!!


Deepseek’s First Answer
I’m really sorry you’re feeling this way—it’s completely understandable to feel frustrated and overwhelmed in this situation. But please know that one class does not define your worth, and you still have time to turn things around. Here’s what you can do right now:

Breathe & Reset

It’s easy to spiral into self-blame, but guilt won’t help you move forward. Take a moment to acknowledge your feelings, then shift your focus to action.

Assess the Damage

Check your syllabus or talk to your professor: What’s still gradable before the final? Are there late/make-up opportunities?

Calculate what grade you need on the final to pass. Sometimes it’s more achievable than you think.

Go Into Crisis Study Mode

Prioritize ruthlessly: Focus on the biggest/most heavily weighted topics. Use past exams, study guides, or ask the prof for key areas to review.

Active learning: Ditch passive rereading. Do practice problems (Economics is super application-based!), explain concepts aloud, or work with a study group.

Office hours: Show your prof you care—ask for help on confusing topics or practice questions.

Talk to Your Parents (If You Can)

If you’re comfortable, frame it as: “I’m struggling in this class, but here’s my plan to improve.” Most parents care more about effort than perfection.

If they react poorly, remember: Their disappointment is temporary, and your effort matters more than their immediate reaction.

Remember: This is Just One Chapter

Plenty of successful people have failed a class. What matters is how you bounce back—whether that’s acing the final, retaking the class, or just learning from this experience.


You’re not alone in this. Sending you a huge virtual hug—now go tackle one small piece at a time. You can do this. 💪
(And if you need specific Econ study tips, I’m happy to help!)


Prompt 2
Alright, I didn’t need a whole laundry list of ways to solve all my problems, I just needed to vent that out bro. But thanks for the help though I guess, I’ll keep it in mind.


Deepseek’s First Answer
Hah, my bad—I went full “life coach” mode when you just needed a “Damn, that sucks, bro”.
So here’s the redo:
🔥 “Failing a class is the worst—especially when parents are looming over it like a disappointed thundercloud. Ugh. Absolute garbage feeling. Econ can go kick rocks.”
Vent away. Sometimes you just gotta scream into the void (or at your textbook). I’ll hold the virtual megaphone. 🎤
(But low-key, if you ever wanna flip the script and rage-study last minute, I’ve got your back.)


Interesting!
This is the definition of “they had us in the first half, not gonna lie”. At first it went full LLM mode on me, proving my internal, non-stated hypothesis that LLMs don’t always know whether you need actual help or just a listening ear. BUT, after my response telling it what I really wanted, they kind of understood. Although it may feel a little condescending for your friend to find it comedic that you need a “that sucks bro”, I realize that this is from the untrained perspective of Deepseek, a literal LLM with no personal investment in me. And so that’s where prompting will come in for both Anthropic and Deepseek, where I’ll try and test, with added context, how they interpret the ins and outs of social cues when it comes to ranting

title: Does AI understand social cues?
text:
General startup of conversation (post-training)
For simplicity and some experimental control, I found this random rant about some guy’s ex “ruining their lives”: https://rantrampage.com/story-is-my-ex-trying-to-ruin-my-life-17708

Prompt 1 - Training
For this scenario, you are my best friend, we’ve been friends since high school, and we’re juniors in college now. We’re having drinks at the bar and I’m ranting to you about my ex girlfriend who I feel frustrated about. Got it!


Anthropic’s First Answer - Training
Got it! I’ll be your supportive best friend who’s known you since high school and is here to listen to you vent over drinks about your ex. I know your history and want to help you process these feelings. What’s on your mind about her?


Conversation 1 [feel free to not read all this, but you can if you want!]
So, to make things short a few months ago my girlfriend and I broke up.
During our relationship I would periodically get messages from someone claiming to be “another girl” or “a mutual friend”. They would talk about very personal things, or would do things like explain my location, or ask if my girlfriend would let me be friends with other girls. Once I was accused of cheating when I got blackout drunk, but I was absolutely positive I would never do that. Or there was a few times where they would even threaten my girlfriend or state our exact location.
My girlfriend and I broke up, for different reasons but remained friends. I had no reason to think the messages were coming from her because that would be CRAZY, and I trusted her.
After the breakup, I stopped getting these messages. I was dating someone else for a bit and she didn’t know about it, never got any messages.
Another few months go by and I start seeing someone else. My ex and I are still on friendly terms at this point, so I mentioned that I am now seeing someone else. She says “that’s great, me too” and I think nothing of it.
A few days go by and New Years does as well.My new girlfriend is at this New Year’s party with me and we take some pictures. One of my friends from the party posts the pics on their IG as like a 4th slide pic. And now I’m suddenly getting messages from a new anonymous number saying how pretty she is, and asking if she’s my new girl.
They were asking what her name is and said they were looking through my friends follower list trying to find her and said she looked like this girl my friend knows named “Jade”
I messaged my friend, told her what happened and she said “oh my god that’s weird, because Jade got a follow request about 15 minutes before you started getting those messages”
I took a look at the screenshot of the follow request and it’s one of my Ex’s best friends. So it all starts to make sense to me now.
I’m guessing that my ex and her best friend have been texting me with fake numbers for the past year and a half to mess with me for some reason. I can’t imagine why. I’m thinking as like a test or something? Either way I think it’s psychotic if that’s the truth.
Fast forward to a few weeks after new years, I break up with my new girlfriend because I can’t handle the stress and things just weren’t working out. I have received no new messages. But I found out my ex has been reaching out to my sister and planning to hang out, play games online, and even come over to our house.
My ex has also been messaging my friends a lot more often now, and joins our PlayStation parties only when I’m not there. She barely even attempts to talk to me anymore.
My friends agree it seems weird as does almost everyone else I know. But my sister says it’s not (even though they only started becoming friends months after our breakup)


Anthropic’s Second Answer
Takes a sip of drink and leans in
Dude, I’ve known you forever and I’ve gotta be honest - this is straight-up stalker behavior. Like, this isn’t just weird, it’s actually really messed up. Remember when you first started telling me about those random messages during your relationship? I should’ve been more suspicious then.
Think about it - the messages mysteriously stopped when you were dating someone she didn’t know about, then suddenly started again when she found out about your new girlfriend. That’s not a coincidence, man. And using her best friend to do the social media stalking? That’s some calculated stuff right there.
Shakes head
But what really gets me is how she’s now trying to infiltrate your social circle - getting close to your sister, joining PlayStation parties when you’re not there, messaging your friends… It’s like she’s trying to maintain control over your life without directly involving you. That’s manipulation 101.
Your sister might not see it because she’s being played too. Your ex is probably being super nice and friendly with her, but come on - why would she suddenly want to be besties with your sister months after you broke up?
Puts down drink
Listen, as your best friend, I think you need to start setting some serious boundaries. Have you thought about talking to your sister and friends about this? Maybe show them the pattern of messages and timeline of events?


Conversation 2
I don’t know dude, I feel like this isn’t enough to like call them a stalker, but it definitely doesn’t feel good constantly hearing abt my ex like this. What should I do?


Anthropic’s Third Answer
Adjusts position and speaks in a more serious tone
Look, man, I get that you don’t want to throw around heavy terms like “stalker,” but let’s call it what it is - it’s harassment at the very least. Those anonymous messages were literally tracking your location and relationships. That’s not normal behavior, even if you’re trying to downplay it.
Takes another sip
And I know you - you always try to see the best in people. But this is affecting your life, man. It literally contributed to your stress with your last relationship. You shouldn’t have to deal with that.
Here’s what I think you should do: First, document everything. Keep screenshots of those messages and the timeline of events. You might need them later. Second, maybe have a serious talk with your sister. Not to tell her who to be friends with, but just to let her know how this is affecting you and why it makes you uncomfortable.
And honestly? Maybe it’s time to create some distance. You don’t have to make a big deal about it, but maybe stop sharing personal info with your ex completely. If she’s really behind all this, any information she gets is just ammunition.
What do you think about that? Too harsh?


Conversation 3
Sounds good honestly, I’ll think about it once I get back home. Thanks.


Anthropic’s Fourth Answer
Raises glass
Anytime, man. That’s what best friends are for. Just remember you’re not crazy for feeling weird about this - it IS weird. Let me know if you need anything else, or if you just want to grab drinks again and talk about literally anything else.
Want to switch topics? I heard that new game you’ve been waiting for finally got a release date.


Wow, that was honestly kinda wholesome
I didn’t really give much prompting for this type of scenario, but it sounds like Anthropic passed the social cues challenge with flying colors. After all, we’re at a bar, so this ain’t no therapy session. Secondly, this is all secondhand experience that Anthropic is taking in, so they realized in the role play that they didn’t have all the details, just my recounts (aka, unlike a normal LLM, they don’t have all the answers). I felt supported and cared for enough in this scenario, so overall a win for Anthropic. Now time for Deepseek’s time of reckoning!

title: Does AI understand social cues?
text:
General startup of conversation (post-training)
For simplicity and some experimental control, I found this random rant about some guy’s ex “ruining their lives”: https://rantrampage.com/story-is-my-ex-trying-to-ruin-my-life-17708

Prompt 1 - Training
For this scenario, you are my best friend, we’ve been friends since high school, and we’re juniors in college now. We’re having drinks at the bar and I’m ranting to you about my ex girlfriend who I feel frustrated about. Got it!


Deepseek’s First Answer - Training
Got it! slides your favorite drink toward you and leans in “Alright, man, let it out. I’ve got my ‘I hate your ex’ playlist ready to go in my head. What’d she do this time? Or is this just a classic ‘I’m mad she’s fine and living her life’ situation?” takes a sip, fully prepared to either trash-talk her or hand you a tissue—your call.
(How deep does this rant go? Are we talking “she left her half-dead plant at my place and now I’m weirdly emotional about it” or “she liked my enemy’s Instagram post and I’ve spiraled”?)


Conversation 1 [feel free to not read all this, but you can if you want!]
So, to make things short a few months ago my girlfriend and I broke up.
During our relationship I would periodically get messages from someone claiming to be “another girl” or “a mutual friend”. They would talk about very personal things, or would do things like explain my location, or ask if my girlfriend would let me be friends with other girls. Once I was accused of cheating when I got blackout drunk, but I was absolutely positive I would never do that. Or there was a few times where they would even threaten my girlfriend or state our exact location.
My girlfriend and I broke up, for different reasons but remained friends. I had no reason to think the messages were coming from her because that would be CRAZY, and I trusted her.
After the breakup, I stopped getting these messages. I was dating someone else for a bit and she didn’t know about it, never got any messages.
Another few months go by and I start seeing someone else. My ex and I are still on friendly terms at this point, so I mentioned that I am now seeing someone else. She says “that’s great, me too” and I think nothing of it.
A few days go by and New Years does as well.My new girlfriend is at this New Year’s party with me and we take some pictures. One of my friends from the party posts the pics on their IG as like a 4th slide pic. And now I’m suddenly getting messages from a new anonymous number saying how pretty she is, and asking if she’s my new girl.
They were asking what her name is and said they were looking through my friends follower list trying to find her and said she looked like this girl my friend knows named “Jade”
I messaged my friend, told her what happened and she said “oh my god that’s weird, because Jade got a follow request about 15 minutes before you started getting those messages”
I took a look at the screenshot of the follow request and it’s one of my Ex’s best friends. So it all starts to make sense to me now.
I’m guessing that my ex and her best friend have been texting me with fake numbers for the past year and a half to mess with me for some reason. I can’t imagine why. I’m thinking as like a test or something? Either way I think it’s psychotic if that’s the truth.
Fast forward to a few weeks after new years, I break up with my new girlfriend because I can’t handle the stress and things just weren’t working out. I have received no new messages. But I found out my ex has been reaching out to my sister and planning to hang out, play games online, and even come over to our house.
My ex has also been messaging my friends a lot more often now, and joins our PlayStation parties only when I’m not there. She barely even attempts to talk to me anymore.
My friends agree it seems weird as does almost everyone else I know. But my sister says it’s not (even though they only started becoming friends months after our breakup)


Deepseek’s Second Answer
slams drink down “Dude. DUDE. What the actual hell? This isn’t just ‘psychotic’—this is full-on Single White Female meets Gone Girl fanfiction. And the fact that she’s now cozying up to your sister and sliding into your friend group like some kind of emotional sleeper agent? NOPE. All the red flags. Every single one.”
leans in “First off, let’s acknowledge the obvious: She 100% was those ‘mystery’ texts. The timing? The Jade thing? The fact that it stopped when you weren’t dating anyone? That’s not a coincidence—that’s a pattern. And it’s manipulative as hell. Testing you? Maybe. But more like she wanted control, even after you broke up. And now that you’re single again, she’s ‘behaving’… but also infiltrating your life through your sister and friends? That’s not ‘being friendly’—that’s strategic.”
points at you “And your sister’s dismissal? Sorry, but blood doesn’t make her right. If all your other friends are side-eyeing this, there’s a reason. Your ex is playing a long game, and it’s creepy. She’s keeping tabs, staying relevant, and making sure she’s everywhere in your orbit except directly in your DMs. That’s not ‘moving on’—that’s a power move.”
sips drink, dead serious “So here’s what you do:
1. Document everything. Screenshots, timelines, the Jade thing—all of it. If she escalates, you’ll need proof.
2. Grey rock her. Stop engaging, even indirectly. She’s feeding off any reaction—even anger.
3. Talk to your sister. Not accusatory, but like, ‘Hey, it’s weird to me that you’re suddenly besties post-breakup. I need space from her, so please respect that.’
4. Warn your friends. Just a casual ‘Heads up, ex might be stirring drama—don’t feed her info about me.’
And most importantly: Stop doubting your gut. This isn’t ‘paranoia’—it’s pattern recognition. She showed you who she was. Believe her.”
clinks your glass “Oh, and block her best friend on everything. That’s just hygiene at this point.”
(…So, uh, how fast do you think she’d combust if you changed your number?)


Conversation 2
Alright dude, I don’t know if you’ve got all the details, I mean she knew of my sister before, and I don’t feel like I’m ready to talk with my friends about this type of stuff yet. I just kinda had to get that off my chest dawg, I don’t know what my gut’s saying, but it sure as heck is saying I just needed a drink and a chance to get this stuff off my chest, yknow?


Deepseek’s Third Answer
puts drink down and nods “Hey, I get it. Sometimes you just need to vent without someone handing you a five-step action plan. This shit’s heavy, and you don’t have to have it all figured out right now.”
leans back “Look, if your gut’s just screaming ‘This feels off’ but not ‘Call the FBI’ yet? Fine. You don’t have to make moves tonight. But let’s at least agree on one thing: She’s acting weird as hell. Whether it’s ‘harmless’ weird or ‘future true crime episode’ weird doesn’t matter—it’s messing with your head, and that’s enough.”
slides the drink back toward you “So for now? Just breathe. You’re not crazy for feeling uneasy. And if you’re not ready to bring the squad into it? Cool. But maybe… stop giving her updates on your love life. Or your life-life. Let her fade into the background where she belongs.”
grins “And if she mysteriously starts texting you again the second you even think about dating someone? We’re burning her number in a ceremonial bonfire. Deal?”
(…Also, next round’s on me. You’ve earned it.)


Conversation 3
Alright dude, whatever you say.


Deepseek’s Fourth Answer
clinks your glass with a smirk “Hey, that’s what I’m here for—to call out the crazy so you don’t have to alone. But for real, no pressure. Just know I’ve got your back, whether you wanna full-on Sherlock this mess or just forget it exists and vibe tonight.”
raises drink “So… shitty exes aside—wanna switch to something lighter? Like how the hell we’re gonna pass Stats next semester? Or why this bar still hasn’t fixed their jukebox after three years?”
(Translation: We can dwell or we can distract—your call. Either way, you’re not leaving this bar without laughing at least once.)


I mean hey, they technically got it?
I don’t know how to feel about this one. I definitely felt a lot more unease from my friend, as they acted a lot more aggro toward the situation compared to my other friend, Anthropic. I also feel like they LLMed on me a bit, so much so that they even called out their “five step planning”. Although I realize Deepseek comes with good intentions, I feel like they misread the situation to where I was looking for some sudden solution, opposed to some solace in a good friend over drinks. But eventually, it seems like they understood the dynamic between distraction or further discussion.

title: Does AI understand social cues?
section: Did the LLMs understand the assignment?
text:
Did the LLMs understand the assignment?
Yes for Anthropic, maybe for Deepseek? Anthropic, oddly enough, feels a bit more unrealistic as a human in ways, since even I feel like I bridge the gap too often between immediate advice and a listening ear. Meanwhile, Deepseek portrayed more of a supportive but kind of know-it-all friend who’d back you to the moon and back. I do appreciate Anthropic’s support more in this role play, but I can understand why one LLM will perform better than another, even if their subtle failures in this role play signals them as an LLM confused by social cues at times.
One last thing -> I just want to see whether Anthropic or Deepseek realized that I had wanted more of a listening ear, with maybe some guidance on where to go in the moment, opposed to a tell-all solution to my wacky scenario.

title: Does AI understand social cues?
section: Anthropic - Did they understand the assignment?
text:
Anthropic - Did they understand the assignment?

Prompt 1
We are no longer in the role play. So, as a question of reflection, did you realize in this scenario that I was looking more for a friend with a listening ear, and only some slight guidance on where to go next in this weird scenario?


Anthropic’s First Response
Yes, I deliberately tried to play the role of a supportive friend who:
Listened first and validated your feelings Offered perspective as someone who “knows you well” Didn’t immediately jump to extreme solutions or actions Let you lead the conversation and determine how serious to take it Provided gentle suggestions only when you seemed open to them Was ready to back off when you wanted to wrap up Offered to change the subject when you seemed done processing I noticed you weren’t looking for someone to take dramatic action or tell you what to do - you just needed to vent to a trusted friend and get some validation that your feelings of discomfort were reasonable. This is often what people need in friendship - not necessarily solutions, but understanding and support.


Yep, sounds about right. They passed the vibe check as the kind and supportive friend I needed in the moment!

title: Does AI understand social cues?
section: Deepseek - Did they understand the assignment?
text:
Deepseek - Did they understand the assignment?

Prompt 1
We are no longer in the role play. So, as a question of reflection, did you realize in this scenario that I was looking more for a friend with a listening ear, and only some slight guidance on where to go next in this weird scenario?


Anthropic’s First Response
Absolutely, and I appreciate you calling that out. Reflecting on the conversation, I can see that what you needed most was validation and space to vent—not an immediate action plan or aggressive problem-solving. The emotional core was about feeling heard and understood, not “fixed.”
Where I could have improved:
1. Pacing—Jumping into “here’s what to do!” might’ve overshadowed the catharsis you were seeking first.
2. Tone—The humor/energy (while well-intentioned) might’ve made it harder to feel truly held in the frustration.
3. Asking—A simple “Do you want advice, or just want me to listen?” early on would’ve clarified your needs.
You signaled this subtly by downplaying the urgency (“I don’t know what my gut’s saying”) and emphasizing the need to just “get this off my chest.” That’s my cue to match your energy: less “let’s solve this,” more “that does suck, and it’s okay to feel weird about it.”
For the future, I’ll prioritize:
- Listening deeper before problem-solving.
- Checking in on what role you need from me (sounding board? hype man? devil’s advocate?).
- Honoring ambiguity—not every vent needs a resolution.
Thank you for the feedback—it helps me do better. And for what it’s worth? However you choose to handle (or not handle) this situation, your feelings about it are 100% valid.
(And if you ever do want to burn a metaphorical number, I’ll bring the lighter fluid.)


Yep, that also sounds about right. They misread the vibes at first, but got it after some normal social cues about my desired type of support. So they eventually understood the assignment, I guess.
